Little_Jimmy_Dickens:
{{Short description|American country music singer-songwriter (1920–2015)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Little Jimmy Dickens |image = Little Jimmy Dickens 1971.JPG |caption = Dickens in 1971 |background = solo_singer |birth_name = James Cecil Dickens |alias = Tater |birth_date = {{birth date|1920|12|19}} |death_date = {{death date and age|2015|1|2|1920|12|19}} |birth_place = [[Bolt, West Virginia]], U.S. |death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. |instrument = [[Guitar]] |genre = [[Country music|Country]] |occupation = Singer, songwriter |years_active = 1936–2014 |label = [[Columbia Records]]
[[Decca Records]]
[[United Artists Records]] |associated_acts = [[Buddy Emmons]], [[Kenneth Carllile]], [[Hank Garland]], [[Red Foley]], [[Minnie Pearl]], [[Hank Williams]], [[Merle Haggard]] |website = |current_members = |past_members = }} '''James Cecil Dickens''' (December 19, 1920 – January 2, 2015), better known by his stage name '''Little Jimmy Dickens''', was an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter famous for his humorous novelty songs, his small size (4'10" [150 cm]), and his [[rhinestone]]-studded outfits (which he is given credit for introducing into live country music performances).{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-30664783|title=BBC News – Country star Little Jimmy Dickens dies aged 94|work=BBC News|date=January 3, 2015 |access-date=January 5, 2015}} He started as a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 1948 and was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1983.{{Cite web |title=Little Jimmy Dickens |url=https://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/hall-of-fame/little-jimmy-dickens |access-date=2024-05-24 |website=Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum |language=en}} Before his death he was the oldest living member of the Grand Ole Opry. ==Early life== Dickens was born in [[Bolt, West Virginia]]. He began his musical career in the late 1930s, performing on radio station [[WJLS (AM)|WJLS]] in [[Beckley, West Virginia]], while attending [[West Virginia University]].{{cite web|last1=Khatchatourian|first1=Maane|title=Little Jimmy Dickens, Oldest Grand Ole Opry Star, Dies at 94|date=January 3, 2015 |url=https://variety.com/2015/music/news/little-jimmy-dickens-oldest-grand-ole-opry-star-dies-at-94-1201391732/|publisher=Variety|access-date=January 3, 2015}} On the radio station, he got his experience with performers like Mel Steele, Molly O'Day and Johnnie Bailes. In the 1940s, Jimmy hosted his own radio programs in places like [[West Virginia]], [[Indiana]], [[Cincinnati]], [[Kansas]] and even [[Ohio]]. He soon quit school to pursue a full-time music career, traveling the country performing on local radio stations under the name "Jimmy the Kid". ==Career== [[File:Little Jimmy Dickens 1955.JPG|thumb|left|Dickens in 1955]] In 1948, Dickens was heard performing on [[WJMK (AM)|WKNX]], a radio station in [[Saginaw, Michigan]], while on location at Buck Lake Ranch, Angola, Indiana. [[Roy Acuff]] introduced him to [[Art Satherley]] at [[Columbia Records]] and to officials from the Grand Ole Opry. Dickens signed with Columbia in September and joined the Opry in August. Around this time he began using the nickname Little Jimmy Dickens, inspired by his short stature.{{cite web|title=Little Jimmy Dickens, Oldest Grand Ole Opry Cast Member, Dead at 94|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/6429370/little-jimmy-dickens-oldest-grand-ole-opry-cast-member-dead-at-94|publisher=Associated Press via Billboard|access-date=January 3, 2015}} Dickens recorded many novelty songs for Columbia, including "Country Boy", "A-Sleeping at the Foot of the Bed", and "I'm Little but I'm Loud".{{cite web|last1=Mansfield|first1=Brian|title=Country Great "Little" Jimmy Dickens Dies at 94|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2015/01/02/little-jimmy-dickens-dies/20994825/|work=USA Today|access-date=January 3, 2015}} His song "Take an Old Cold Tater (And Wait)" inspired [[Hank Williams]] to nickname him Tater. Later, telling Dickens he needed a hit, Williams wrote "[[Hey Good Lookin' (song)|Hey Good Lookin']]" in only 20 minutes while on a plane with Dickens, [[Minnie Pearl]], and Pearl's husband, Henry Cannon.{{cite book |last=Masino |first=Susan |date=2011 |title=Family Tradition: Three Generations of Hank Williams |url=https://archive.org/details/familytraditiont00masi |url-access=registration |quote=jimmy dickens hank williams hey good lookin minnie pearl plane. |location=Montclair, New Jersey |publisher=Backbeat Books |page=[https://archive.org/details/familytraditiont00masi/page/67 67] |isbn=978-1-61713-006-9}} A week later, Williams recorded the song himself, jokingly telling Dickens, "That song's too good for you!",{{cite web|last1=Lavallee|first1=Michelle|title=Little Jimmy Dickens: Country Singer to Opry Legend|url=http://www.axs.com/little-jimmy-dickens-country-singer-to-opry-legend-31404|publisher=AXS|access-date=January 3, 2015}} to which Dickens replied, "Much obliged, Hiram." In 1950, Dickens formed the Country Boys with musicians Jabbo Arrington, [[Grady Martin]], [[Bob Moore (musician)|Bob Moore]], and [[Thumbs Carllile]]. It was during this time that he discovered future Country Music Hall of Famer [[Marty Robbins]] at a [[Phoenix, Arizona]], television station while on tour with the Grand Ole Opry road show. In 1957, Dickens left the Grand Ole Opry to tour with the ''Philip Morris Country Music Show''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_5943693,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20150103214319/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_5943693,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 3, 2015|title=Artists : Artists A to Z : Little Jimmy Dickens Biography : Great American Country|access-date=January 5, 2015}} In 1962, Dickens had his first top-10 country hit since 1954 with "The Violet and a Rose". In 1964, he became the first country artist to circle the globe while on tour. He also made numerous appearances on television, including on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]''. In 1965, he released his biggest hit, "[[May the Bird of Paradise Fly Up Your Nose]]", which reached number 1 on the country chart and number 15 on the pop chart. In the late 1960s, Dickens left Columbia for [[Decca Records]] before moving again to [[United Artists]] in 1971.{{cite web|url=http://www.udiscovermusic.com/farewell-little-jimmy-dickens|title=Farewell to 'Little' Jimmy Dickens|date=January 3, 2015 |publisher=uDiscovermusic.com|access-date=January 5, 2015}} That same year, he married his wife, Mona,{{cite web|url=http://www.brentwoodhomepage.com/little-jimmy-dickens-december-filled-with-milestones-cms-3965#.VKhivyeGrzY|title=Little Jimmy Dickens' December Filled with Milestones|publisher=BrentwoodHomePage.com|access-date=January 5, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103235221/http://www.brentwoodhomepage.com/little-jimmy-dickens-december-filled-with-milestones-cms-3965#.VKhivyeGrzY|archive-date=January 3, 2015|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.masoncountynews.com/news/30164/|title=Grand Ole Opry Stars Little Jimmy Dickens and Darrell McCall At Llano Country Opry: Events|date=May 15, 2010|work=Mason County News|access-date=January 5, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104003901/http://www.masoncountynews.com/news/30164/|archive-date=January 4, 2015|df=mdy-all}} and in 1975 he returned to the Grand Ole Opry. In 1983. Dickens was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.{{cite web|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/little-jimmy-dickens|title=Little Jimmy Dickens|publisher=CountryMusicHallofFame.org|access-date=January 5, 2015}} Dickens joined producers [[Randall Franks]] and [[Alan Autry]] for the ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)|In the Heat of the Night]]'' cast CD ''Christmas Time's A Comin’'', performing "Jingle Bells" with the cast. The CD was released by Sonlite and MGM/UA and was one of the most popular Christmas releases of 1991 and 1992 with Southern retailers. ===Later career=== In 1984, Dickens appeared in [[Hank Williams Jr.|Hank Williams Jr.'s]] music video for the hit single "[[All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight]]". [[File:Little Jimmy Dickens.jpg|thumb|Dickens performing at the [[Grand Ole Opry House]] in 2004. Notice the six-foot circle of oak which was cut from the corner of the [[Ryman Auditorium]]'s stage and inlaid into center stage at the Grand Ole Opry House]] Toward the end of his life, Dickens made appearances in a number of music videos by fellow West Virginia native and country musician [[Brad Paisley]]. He was also featured on several of Paisley's albums in bonus comedy tracks, along with other Opry mainstays such as [[George Jones]] and [[Bill Anderson (country music)|Bill Anderson]]. They were collectively referred to as the Kung-Pao Buckaroos. With the death of [[Hank Locklin]] in March 2009, Dickens became the oldest living member of the Grand Ole Opry, at the age of 90. He made regular appearances as a host at the Opry, often with the self-deprecating joke that he was also known as "[[Willie Nelson]] after taxes", playing on his resemblance to Nelson in his later years, [[The IRS Tapes: Who'll Buy My Memories?|Nelson's highly publicized problems with the Internal Revenue Service]], and Dickens' own short stature. At the [[2011 Country Music Association Awards|2011 CMA Awards]], Dickens was dressed as [[Justin Bieber]] and made fun of Bieber's then-current [[paternity (law)|paternity]] scandal. ==Personal life== Dickens married Connie Chapman in 1944; the marriage ended in divorce in 1955. Later that year, he married Ernestine Jones; she died in 1968 in an automobile accident while traveling in Texas. He married Mona Evans in 1971.{{cite web |url=http://www.axs.com/little-jimmy-dickens-passes-away-at-94-his-life-death-and-legacy-36208/ |title=Little Jimmy Dickens Passes Away at 94; His Life, Death and Legacy |last=Cooke |first=Sherryjane |date=January 8, 2015 |publisher=AXS.com |access-date=January 1, 2017}} They had two daughters, Pamela Detert and Lisa King.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/little-jimmy-dickens-dead-94-cardiac-arrest-opry|title=Little Jimmy Dickens Has Died at the Age of 94|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=January 5, 2015}} ==Death== Dickens was hospitalized after a stroke on December 25, 2014, six days after marking his birthday in what would be his last appearance on the Opry. He died of cardiac arrest on January 2, 2015, at the age of 94.{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Peter|title=Little Jimmy Dickens, beloved 'Opry' star, dies at 94|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2015/01/02/little-jimmy-dickens-opry-star-dies-obit/21210809/|access-date=January 3, 2015|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|date=January 3, 2015}} After his funeral on January 8, 2015, at the [[Grand Ole Opry House]], Dickens was entombed in the Cross Mausoleum at [[Woodlawn Memorial Park (Nashville, Tennessee)|Woodlawn Memorial Park]] in Nashville.{{cite web|url=http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/nashville-edge/Little-Jimmy-Dickens-Funeral-Held-At-Grand-Ole-Opry-287906551.html|title=Little Jimmy Dickens' Funeral Held At Grand Ole Opry|work=NewsChannel5.com|access-date=January 8, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109053715/http://www.jrn.com/newschannel5/nashville-edge/Little-Jimmy-Dickens-Funeral-Held-At-Grand-Ole-Opry-287906551.html|archive-date=January
